columns.text: In this exercise, we will examine stock valuation by using the price-to-earnings (PE) ratio. We are given some historical information for the last 4 years and by using this information we must calculate the target price one year from now.

Let's start by explaining what price-to-earnings (PE) ratio is. A price-to-earnings (PE) ratio is used to determine a stock's relative value among investors and financial analysts. It is commonly used to tell whether a company is overpriced or underpriced. Additionally, one may compare the PE ratio of a company to that of other companies in the same industry or the S&P 500 index. In other words, the price-to-earnings (PE) ratio **represents the amount of money an investor would need to invest in a business to gain $1 of its earnings.** Because of this, the P/E ratio is also known as the price multiple. We can calculate the price-to-earnings (PE) ratio by dividing the current stock price by earnings per share: $$\text{PE Ratio} = \dfrac{\text{Current Stock Price}}{\text{Earning Per Share}} \tag{1}$$

We are given the following information:

1. In the first year the high price is $27.43, the low price is \$19.86 and the earnings per share are 1.35.

2. In the second year the high price is $26.32, the low price is \$20.18 and the earnings per share are 1.58.

3. In the third year the high price is $30.42, the low price is \$25.65 and the earnings per share are 1.51.

4. In the fourth year the high price is $37.01, the low price is \$26.41 and the earnings per share are 1.85

We need to find the average price-to-earnings ratio (PE) for these 4 years. Considering we have two prices, the lower price and the higher price, we will have two averages. One average will be the average of PE ratios calculated using the lower price and the other will be the average of the ratios that were calculated using the higher price.

The price-to-earnings ratios (PE) for the first year are: $$\text{PE Ratio}_\text{1st year high} = \dfrac{\$27.43}{1.35} = 20.31851$$ $$\text{PE Ratio}_\text{1st year low} = \dfrac{\$19.86}{1.35} = 14.71111$$

The price-to-earnings ratios (PE) for the second year are: $$\text{PE Ratio}_\text{2nd year high} = \dfrac{\$26.32}{1.58} = 16.65822$$ $$\text{PE Ratio}_\text{2nd year low} = \dfrac{\$20.18}{1.58} = 12.77215$$

The price-to-earnings ratios (PE) for the third year are: $$\text{PE Ratio}_\text{3rd year high} = \dfrac{\$30.42}{1.51} = 20.14569$$ $$\text{PE Ratio}_\text{3rd year low} = \dfrac{\$25.65}{1.51} = 16.98675$$

The price-to-earnings ratios (PE) for the fourth year are: $$\text{PE Ratio}_\text{4th year high} = \dfrac{\$37.01}{1.85} = 20.0054$$ $$\text{PE Ratio}_\text{4th year low} = \dfrac{\$26.41}{1.85} = 14.27567$$

Now we can calculate the two average price-to-earnings ratio (PE) , one using the higher values and the other using the lower values: $$\begin{aligned} \text{PE Ratio}_\text{ higher average} &= \dfrac{20.31851 + 16.65822 + 20.14569 + 20.0054}{4} \\[15pt] &= 19.281955 \end{aligned}$$ $$\begin{aligned} \text{PE Ratio}_\text{ lower average} &= \dfrac{14.71111 + 12.77215 + 16.98675 + 14.27567}{4} \\[15pt] &= 14.68642 \end{aligned}$$

Recall that the target price is calculated as:

$$\text{Target Price} = \text{Estimated earnings} \times \text{PE Ratio} \tag{2}$$

and estimated earnings are calculated as:

$$\text{Estimated earnings} = \text{Current earnings} \times (1 + g)^n \tag{3}$$

where:

- $g$ - the rate at which earnings grow
- $n$ - the number of compounding periods. In our case, this is the number of years from today for which we need to calculate the price

We need to calculate the future stock price one year from now. 

Hence, the number of compounding periods is $n$ is 1. 

By inputting the values into Eq.$(2)$, we get the following estimated earnings for one year from now:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Estimated earnings} &= \text{Current earnings per share} \times (1 + g)^n \\[10pt]
&= \$1.85 \times (1 + 9\%)^1 \\[10pt]
&= \$2.0165
\end{aligned}$$

Now, we can input the estimated earnings and the average PE ratios into Eq.$(3)$ to calculate the target prices one year from now:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Target Price}_\text{ higher} &= \$2.0165 \times 19.281955 \\[10pt]
&= \$38.88206
\end{aligned}$$

**The higher target price one year from now is \$38.88206.**

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Target Price}_\text{ lower} &= \$2.0165 \times 14.68642 \\[10pt]
&= \$29.61516593
\end{aligned}$$

**The lower target price one year from now is \$29.61516593.**

**Let's recap what we did in this exercise!** We were given a set of values for earnings per share and current prices for each year. Instead of being given only one value of current price, we were given two values - one value being the high price and the other being the low price. We then used these values to calculate two average price-to-earnings ratios (PE), one using the lower values of the current price and the other using the higher values. Then, by using these average price-to-earnings ratios (PE) we found the target prices for one year from now.
